poem:
Home Office

He came as a boy,  
salt on his tongue, Britain in his hands.  
Sixty years and still they ask for paper  
as if flesh were forgery.

Hospital out; the street in.  
A bus shelter becomes address,  
toilets a chapel, food-bank bread a sacrament.

They apologise, then mislay him again—  
a pension denied, a life misfiled.  
"I'm part of this country," he says;  
the country looks away.
